result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Riley Z. McLemore

records.addlTxt:
10:02 AM Cases called: 20CF1121, 21CF1094, 21CF1189, 21CF1239, 22CF764, 22CT176 & 22CT211. Defendant Riley Z. McLemore in court.  Attorney Robert Allen Thorson in court for Riley Z. McLemore.  Attorney Kelly Ronquist in court for State of Wisconsin. State in compliance with victim notification requirements.  

Defendant waives right to a preliminary hearing in 21CF1094, 21CF1189, 21CF1239 & 22CF764 and Court accepts waiver in each of those files and binds the matter over for an arraignment. 

Defense needs more time to work out an agreement, but indicates they may be close to reaching an agreement.  Arraignment and possible Plea Hearing: 12/06/22 at 3:30pm in person.
Status conference on September 9, 2022 at 01:30 pm.

9:30 AM cases 20CF1121, 21CF1094, 21CF1189, 21CF1239, 22CF764, 22CT176, 22CT211 called. Defendant Riley Z. McLemore in court.  Attorney Robert Thorsen in court via Zoom video. Prosecuting attorney Peter J. Rindal in court for the State of Wisconsin. There has been an offer from the State. State notes the preliminary hearing has not been addressed in felony files. 
A status conference is scheduled for 9/9/22 at 1:30 PM.
